text: chance the rapper acid rap hi everyone
Anthony Fantana here intranets busiest
music nerd and it's time for you review
the new chance the rapper mixtape acid
rap chance the rapper is a Chicago
rapper and singer and this is his
follow-up project to the 10-day mixtape
that dropped last year which you could
definitely say is kind of overlooked
considering just how much speed hype
popularity that chance is gaining off
this new project and if you compare acid
rap to 10-day you can definitely see an
uptick in quality or at least
memorability because there are less
moments on 10-day that seem to feature
that very quirky nutty over-the-top
personality that people seem to be
celebrating on this new project plus the
production on this new project is flashy
er the recording quality is better too
now as far as the personality that
chance brings on this mixtape it seems
to be much of what his focus lies in
chance is personality his voice that he
delivers his raps and his singing with
is done in this sort of high mid pitch
register and there's a sharp rasp in a
lot of his vocals too and he comes off
incredibly energetic for somebody whose
head seems to be very riddled with drugs
acid xanax weed and alcohol seem to be
major players and a lot of chances
lyrics with Molly and wax as well as
many other things kind of hopping into
play cameo roles in fact the song push a
man kind of paints this drug-dealer
image of him in the hook of the song
anyway with very smooth jazzy production
and the song is peppered with his
nananana yeah ad-lib that he likes to
throw around everywhere
when rapping chance paces his words out
in this Rastafari style flow and the
hook on this track is sort of backed up
with some chopped and screwed vocals
it's a killer hook there's actually a
bit of space as soon as this first
portion of the song finishes and then it
leads into a sec
portion and I mean it's a big gap of
literally silence which according to
Twitter chants says that if you're on
acid while listening to this project
don't skip it because it takes away all
the feeling but while listening to this
I was pretty sober so I'm not sure if I
should skip it
or sit through it either way the track
breaks into this very Spacey
lush synth heavy beat that feels very
nocturnal and has a huge good kid maad
city kind of vibe to it and when chance
finally pops into the track his flow
gives off the same feel and on this
latter portion of the track which is
very quiet very subtle chance paints
himself as this guy with a blunt on his
lips he's got his 9 on his hip and it's
got the shit's at this point the song
chance comes off very druggie very
violent but then he sort of turns around
and wonders why the media doesn't really
cover the extreme gang violence that
goes on in Chicago it feels like to me
that chance has a love-hate relationship
with where he comes from and violence as
well while he sees Chicago as a place
that has personality and has built him
as a person he hates the violence that
goes on there and while he does seem to
fear it in a very serious and real way
he does use it occasionally to sort of
further his persona maybe just sort of
throwing some tough talk out there in
order to counteract some of the more
vulnerable and personal moments that are
spread throughout this tape musically he
even celebrates Chicago a little bit
with some Juke influence on the beats
from the opening track and the closing
track on here too which I loved still on
this track and maybe a few other moments
on this tape chance is taking some
really important social issues in his
lyrics setting them up against a great
instrumental but the urgency of these
issues to me doesn't really come through
all the time chance may have some strong
personal feelings about some of the
stuff he brings up but he doesn't come
off to me as like a serious voice on
some of these topics usually when he
tries to take on a tangle the difficult
issue like drug addiction or violence or
one's relation with God it comes off
very surface and just barely scratched I
feel like I'm just left with some
messages and some images sometimes that
thickly glazed over with a layer of
inebriation
there are moments on acid rap though
where chances very personal relationship
with drugs does seem to help them out
and lead to some real song inspiration
like on the track cocoa butter kisses
not only is the instrumental killer on
this thing really smooth great organs on
this track fantastic melody very
memorable
really tasteful hook soulful singing
coming from chance and I love the
sentiment of this track basically
talking about how when you smoke a lot
whether it be cigarettes whether it be
pot you have your life especially your
relationships with people who aren't in
on that part of your life kind of change
because the smell is there people who
you have a relationship might have
strong feelings against you smoking it's
a part of smoking that is is really real
but it's an element of this life that
isn't really explored through song all
too often because there's nothing
glorious about it it's kind of awkward
and chance does a great job of capturing
this awkwardness on a track with a guest
verse from Twista that is absolutely
awesome as acid rap continues chance
comes through and exposes his more
tender side which I'm sure a lot of you
saw coming he delivers a pretty
interesting love song with the track
lost which makes the idea of dropping
acid with someone sound really romantic
the track has a beautiful piano led
production awesome jazzy flute and
guitar on this thing lyrically chants
delves a little bit into the specifics
of the relationship that he has with
this girl and though the track does have
a really sweet sentiment to it there is
a bit of speculation left in the verse
drop by no-name gypsy which is a great
verse where we are left off with the
line where she says the only time he
really loves her is naked in her dream
sort of illustrating some kind of
disconnect between the two of them when
maybe they're not high the album gets
even better on the next two tracks with
the track everybody something which is a
really fantastic sentiment on this album
just talking about everybody is
somebody's everything that's essentially
the message of the song it's talking
about relationships whether they be
family or romantic and though chances
Ryan's come off angry sometimes on this
track he goes on to say that he is who
he is because someone loved
to help him beat his demons and
basically get him through harder times
there's a funny spot toward the end of
the track where he goes on and on about
how he talks white or just sort of has
this white inflection to the way that he
converses in everyday life and sort of
an underlying subtlety to this point in
the track is that he uses a flow that
feels completely ripped from Eminem's
Slim Shady LP Chan's had some great
wordplay toward the back end of this
track and the way he sings on the song
is just another reminder that he has a
very strange voice but can definitely
sing I love the song that's love I feel
like it's a great middle point on this
album another passion is spot on here
but for me the LP really loses steam
after this moment acid rap continues
with three pretty major features from
childish gambino action bronson and
absol on the next three tracks but i
really feel like these songs are some of
the most lackluster on the album and it
really has nothing to do with the
features whatsoever i feel like on these
particular tracks the production is the
weakest a lot of chances hooks on these
songs are the most forgettable and
half-assed and I don't really feel like
there's a strong message or sentiment to
any of the tracks either they just feel
like really breezy moments the track
favorite song is really poppy it has a
sweet instrumental but the moment were
chance flies in with thee that's my jam
that's my damn but that's gonna that's
gonna do it just feels like he's not
even trying the song Yan yak comes
through with that Rastafari flow again I
like the heavy bass line on this track
and action bronson delivers a
fantastically just over-the-top and
funny verse on this song but chance
essentially makes a hook out of his
somewhat obnoxious ad-lib that I feel
like keep peppers way too hard on the
album anyway and smoke again maybe this
track is my least favorite of the three
the beat to me doesn't really feel like
anything but a trap beat with the hi-hat
stripped out of it chances lyrics don't
really hit me in in any way whatsoever
no surprises nothing really all that
interesting and absol on this track may
have dropped one of his most lackluster
guest verses that I've ever
Hurd especially with the line where he
says no doubt like Gwen Stefani's group
let me put my mouth where you potty boo
after these moments the album returns
back to that production that feels very
refined its melodic it's chill it's
sweet on the ears but on the track acid
rain though chance is getting really
nostalgic in his lyrics it just feels
like there are too many moments on this
track where he's grasping for something
to struggle over personally and the
closer was really the best thing the end
of this album had to offer
overall I didn't really dislike this
mixtape I thought I was really likable
and I liked the personality that chance
brought to the table and a lot of the
hooks on the first half of this LP for
sure there is reason to celebrate
chances growing popularity because he is
certainly different than your average
ignorant Trapp rapper but with a lot of
the things that he says in his lyrics I
don't really feel like he's a breath of
fresh air or anything like that because
lyrically he doesn't really come off as
enlightened or as progressive as one
would assume just by listening to his
out-there persona I guess there are just
a lot of moments where he lets hooks
beats and his ad-libs carry his songs
from beginning to end there are these
spots on this album where he feels like
nothing more than a goofy acid dropping
cartoon character who is way too jittery
and unfocused to drop some lines that
would really sort of widen some eyes and
surprise some people when it comes to
some of the serious topics that he
attempts to tackle on some of these
tracks overall I'm feeling a decent two
strong six on this tape if you've given
it a listen what did you think of it did
you love it did you hate it why what do
you think I should review next and
that's it
Anthony Fantana chance the rapper
forever
you
you
